abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is highly
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, with substantial
            institutional development impacts. Lessons reflect the
            positive factors which facilitated these impressive results.
            Primarily, client ownership, and sustained political, and
            financial support reinforce their fundamental value in the
            development of project implementation, and in preventing
            delays, and/or overcoming problems, respectively. Contrary
            to criticism of being an ambitious, and complex project, -
            including the Biomedical sciences building (Biomedicum),
            which brought together various medical specialties - it was
            this investment, and related policy programs, that proved
            common to academia, policymakers, and the community at
            large, and, precisely this common focal point, helped
            overcome the risk of complex design. However, the highly
            politicized capacity building for the development of health
            policy, was perceived as a potential threat to traditional
            "political" policy development, thus, the absence
            of policy was preferred over policy development.
            Nonetheless, more attention could have been given to
            consultation, and participation, with a project design more
            focused on attracting stakeholders' interest on those
            issues. The significant value the Bank has in providing
            impartial technical know-how, was evidenced by the
            construction of the Biomedicum, through technical expertise,
            while financing, and guaranteeing sustainable,
            cost-effective solutions.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Estonia Health Project will provide
            technical assistance, fellowships, training, laboratory and
            teaching equipment, computer hardware and software, civil
            works and refurbishment of facilities, furniture and fixed
            equipment, and incremental recurrent costs for activities
            centered in the reform process. The project, which will be
            implemented over a four-year period by the Ministry of
            Social Affairs (MSA), the University of Tartu, and the
            Central Health Insurance Agency (CHIA), will consist of the
            following components: (a) health system reorientation which
            will support the MSA's new national health strategy;
            (b) development of human resources for health which will
            carry out programs for training and re-training health
            professionals and personnel; (c) efficient management of
            financial resources which will improve the management
            capacity of the CHIA and the local health insurance funds
            and to help establish clear links between these funds and
            health care providers; and (d) a project coordination unit
            which will oversee project implementation and management and
            will strengthen MSA's capacity to coordinate external
            assistance for health.
